title: HTML intro
desc: What is HTML markup language used for and how are they structured?

title: HTML Basic Structure <!DOCTYPE html>
desc: Learn about the main formatting of all HTML documents, tags, images, and links

title: Elements <tagname> </tagname>
desc: Learn about tags and the markup ability of each tag.

title: Attributes href=, title=
desc: Attributes provide additional information about HTML elements.

title: Headings <h1>
desc: Headings range in size but are there for indexing and navigating the user through different sections of your content

title:
Paragraphs

& Line Break
desc: You can use paragraphs to seperate information

title: Styles style="property:value" (DO NOT USE)
desc: Directly embed styling to your elements.

title: Text Formatting Elements <b> <i>
desc: Bold, italicize, delete, important etc...define text with meaning

title: Quotations and Citation <blockquote> <cite>
desc: Show quotes, abbreviations, citations etc...

title: Computer Code <code>
desc: Display computer code, variables, keyboard etc...

title: Comments <!-- -->
desc: Help document your code

title: Colors
desc: Display colors using red, green and blue (RGB)

title: Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) - DO NOT EMBED
desc: Using style tags you can style multiple properties for each element

title: Links <a href="">
desc: Link to other websites for users to navigate to.

title: Images
desc: Embed images to your document for visual displays

title: Tables <table>
desc: Create tables to display and organize data

title: Lists <ul>, <ol>, <li>
desc: You can list information via bullet points using lists

title: Block and Inline Elements
desc: Each element has different styles in which they take up whole width of the line or flow in place of the line

title: Classes class=
desc: Use class to create set css styles that can be applied to any element to display in a similar style.

title: Layout <div>
desc: You can format your document into different sections via divs

title: Responsive Web Design (!important)
desc: Using css and html you can resize your page to fit and look nice on a desktop, tablet or phone.

title: Iframes
desc: Use iframes to display other web pages within your current page.

title: Javascript <script>
desc: Javascript helps make your pages more interactive and also dynamic.

title: Head <head>
desc: Use head tag to put meta data, stylesheets, scripts and titles

title: Entities
desc: There are reserved characters for the browser so in order to use reserved keywords in html you will have to use entity names or numbers

title: Symbol Entities
desc: There are reserved characters for the browser so in order to use reserved keywords in html you will have to use entity names or numbers

title: Encoding (char set)
desc: Using meta data you can tell the browser what language and character sets your code will use.

title: Uniform Resource Locators (URL Encode)
desc: Send data from html to another address using http protocols

title: Extensible Hypertext Markup Language (XHTML)
desc: Identical to HTML but more stricter on rules

title: Forms <form>
desc: Form elements are used to collect information from user.

title: Form Elements <input> <textarea> <button>
desc: There are many tags that help collect information: input, textarea, button, keygen, output, datalist, option...

title: Input Types <input type=>
desc: There are many ways to get user input via text, password, radio btn, checkboxes.

title: Input Attributes
desc: Attributes can be added to block forms, set size or store value in variable

title: HTML5 Intro
desc: Provides new better elements, graphics, multimedia and APIs

title: HTML5 Graphics
desc: Use canvas to draw onto page and include SVG graphics.

title: HTML5 Multimedia
desc: Multimedia on the web, is sound, music, videos, movies, and animations.

title: HTML5 APIs
desc: Application Programming Interfaces

title: HTML References
desc: Tag list, attributes, events, canvas, media, doctype, color, char, url, lang, messages, methods, px, keyboard shortcuts
